title: Genetic background of juvenile idiopathic arthritis.
summary: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is the most common chronic rheumatologic disease in children. ...
abstract: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is the most common chronic rheumatologic disease in children. JIA is a group of disorders that share the clinical manifestation of chronic joint inflammation. The human leukocyte antigen region (HLA) seems to be a major susceptibility locus for JIA that is estimated to account for 17% of familial segregation of the disease. To date, around 20 non-HLA loci conferring susceptibility to JIA were found. At least a half of those are shared between JIA and rheumatoid arthritis (RA), an adult rheumatic disease, thereby suggesting for similarity of pathogenic mechanisms of both diseases. New findings also suggest for a likely role of epigenetic alterations in the pathogenesis of JIA that should be investigated in the future.
